metadata.title: Working Knights Textbook of Pediatric Emergency Medicine, Fifth Edition Working Knights

body_text.text: Are there any frustrated emergency physicians out there? How about joyous or puzzled or down-trodden or overworked ones? How about any combination of the above? Or perhaps you cycle between all these options and more. I have got the book for you.

Emergency physician, father, husband, and writer Edwin Leapdfamiliar to many of us through his monthly column in Emergency Medicine Newsdhas recently released a collection of essays entitled ''Working Knights.'' The clever title derives from the fact that Dr. Leap works mostly nights, and his first column for Emergency Medicine News was ''The White Knights of Medicine.'' This piece spoke to the collective good we provide as emergency physicians.

As he relates in one of his essays, Dr. Leap trained at Methodist Hospital in Indiana and now practices at rural Oconee Memorial Hospital in South Carolina. He brings the breadth of his experience as a physician, parent, spouse, and keen observer of humanity to his writing. There's also a hint of his religious beliefs here.

Joy and sorrow, sarcasm and pity, hope and despair, fantasy and a healthy dose of seasoned reality all intertwine in ''Working Knights'' to create a wonderful tapestry of thoughts and emotions reflective of the realities of modern emergency medicine practice and lifestyle. You'll likely see yourselves and your colleagues in the pages of this book.

There are powerful telling moments in this slim volume of 57 stories and poems. ''Barbarians Are Alive and Well'' chronicles Leap's experience caring for a young man injured and felled by a barbarous attacker simply because he offered the barbarian's girlfriend his seat on a crowded bus. Probably many of us have shared his anguish as we've tended to society's victims. ''Breath Shepherd'' is a touching personal account of the author's nocturnal wanderings within the bedrooms of his own home watching over the respirations of his wife and 4 children. ''Breath is life,'' he writes near the end of the essay, and, a paragraph later, ''So there I am, a guardian of breath.'' For me, this represents truly a great connection between the work we all do and the personal flocks we tend.

There are occasionally times when a strong editorial presence would have benefited this book. However, overall, ''Working Knights'' is a good, easy read. Some of the sentences, and the essays that contain them, rise to the level of greatness. Three of my favorites follow: ''This year I have tried on several sicknesses,'' ''I hope to be obsolete someday,'' and ''Sometimes a little brutal honesty is just what the doctor ordered.'' These sang to me because I've either had the experience (sickness), mused over the thought (obsolescence would be nice), or longed to speak my mind (honestly).

In short, this is the real deal: words of wisdom, earned through years of life, love, and work experience. You won't always agree with him, but Dr. Leap will challenge you to think about the life you lead as an emergency physician. I'd strongly recommend adding ''Working Knights'' to your required reading list. It might become the book you turn to after a series of busy shifts in an effort to regain your balance or fine tune your perspective. The Textbook of Pediatric Emergency Medicine has been a core resource of pediatric emergency medicine fellowships and within emergency medicine residencies since its first edition in 1983. In this edition, we see a significant evolution and advancement from the previous version. 1 Added to the fifth edition is a section on severe acute respiratory syndrome and, in the procedures section, the use of ultrasonography in the emergency department. Other sections have been modernized to reflect the changes in pediatric emergency medicine.

Some new features include a list of algorithms at the beginning of the book, with corresponding page listings for easy reference. Also, the color plates have been moved to the beginning of the book for easier location and referral. The strengths of the book are many. It has a well-written and referenced format designed to aid with clinical decisionmaking. The textbook also contains many tables and charts, as well as imbedded pictures to augment the discussion. Every chapter ends with a list of suggested readings in which the clinician can find further information if needed.

There are several resources in the book that allow the clinician to quickly reference questions outside the index and table of contents. The ''Signs and Symptoms'' section is a good place to begin when faced with a specific presentation that one cannot diagnose or when one is in need of more information. The algorithm list is another excellent method to reference one's clinical dilemma. Either section could support the clinician in finding the answers when he or she is unsure of the exact question. Additionally, there are many good tables, diagrams, and black-and-white pictures that allow for quick viewing of the material being discussed.

Weaknesses have more to do with the scope of the book. As a textbook, it does well overall, but it falls short in several areas when compared to more specialized texts. The procedure section is well illustrated but is not as detailed as a textbook dedicated to procedures such as the Roberts and Hedges 2 Clinical Procedures in Emergency Medicine. The ''Emergency Drug Compendium'' is likewise useful, but most clinicians would probably use a more specific drug reference or a PDAsupported application. The ultrasonographic section consists primarily of illustrations, with little instruction in the use and diagnosis capability of ultrasonography. There are now ultrasonography-dedicated textbooks that are more informative. Finally, the parental handouts are not printed for copying or perforated for removal, so their use would be only as a reference.

In conclusion, the Textbook of Pediatric Emergency Medicine is a well-written reference textbook that I would recommend to all pediatric emergency medicine fellows, as well as all emergency physicians. This textbook should serve as your guide when faced with a pediatric clinical concern and as a reference in your library. I would also suggest that you have other references for more detailed reading, specifically about procedures, drug information, and ultrasonographic instruction.
Mark Daniel Lopez, MD Departments of Emergency Medicine and Pediatrics Medical College of Georgia Augusta, GA
